body.p: Louisville, Jefferson County, Kentucky workhouse. Held petty criminals, the poor, and diseased residents of the city. Opened in 1832 in a building on Chestnut Street to confine both male and female prisoners and wards. Relocated in 1850 to a brick structure on Payne Street near Cave Hill Cemetery. Included 400 cells and 12 dungeons. Managed by a committee of three trustees and a superintendent. Daily operations overseen by an elected keeper who served one-year terms. The keeper appointed day and night guards to prevent escapes and transport prisoners from the Louisville City Court to the Work House. Prisoners worked twelve-hour days in the months of April through September and ten-hour days in the months of October through March. Prisoner duties included rock-breaking to support the construction of city roads and supply a stone quarry in Louisville.
